sourceDesc.p:
This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed REED collections - Inns of Court, Ecclesiastical London, and Civic London to 1558. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
Ecclesiastical London
Mary C. Erler
University of Toronto Press and The British Library. 2008
504
978-0-8020-9858-0 978-0-7123-5024-2
Inns of Court
Alan H. Nelson
John R. Elliott, Jr
Boydell & Brewer 2010
1174 3
978-1-84384-259-0
Civic London to 1558
Ann Lancashire
David J. Parkinson
Boydell & Brewer 2015
3 1795
978-1-84384-399-3

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

REED London Online is a prototype online collection developing from the Records of Early English Drama (REED) in partnership with the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) and supported by Bucknell University. It aims to establish an openly accessible online scholarly and pedagogical resource of London-centric documentary, editorial, and bibliographic materials related to performance, theatre, and music spanning the period 1100-1642. With support from an NHPRC-Mellon Planning Grant for Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives and CANARIE Research Software Program grants, REED London is creating new environments for scholarly presentation of archival materials gathered from legal, ecclesiastical, civic, political, and personal archival sources in and around London. The objective of the REED London project team is to build a stable, extensible publication environment that optimizes access to these compiled materials in ways that respond to scholars’ research interests across disciplines. Consulting with other planning grant recipients will be invaluable to ensuring that REED London’s production and publication environment is in line with standards laid out in the NHPRC-Mellon grant objectives. It is hoped that the progress REED London and CWRC make will also inform the larger dialogue about best practices among funded teams.

category.catDesc: All Hallows by the Tower Muniments Room

revisionDesc.change: Added repositories and abbreviations to TEI header for Archivo General de Simancas, GI Arch, IT Arch, IT Lib, LI Arch, LI Lib, MT Arch, and MT Lib
Replaced current REED editorial staff section in TEI header with names of staff responsible for three London collections
Updated master TEI header to refer to ongoing funding for REED London Online and to recognize repositories and record types as project expands.

div.head: (21 November)
div.ab: Twoo xvnes graunted by the same Cytie, for the discharginge of the charges of the same Cytie at the coronacion of Quene Elisabeth At this coimen counsell it was ordred graunted and agreed by the same That there shalbe collected levied and gathered of the cytesens and other Inhabytantes of this cytie twoo hole and entyer xvnes with all convenyent spede to be Levyed accordinge to thauncyent custome vsed in this cytie in that behalfe aswell for the accustomed present to be gyven to the quenes moste excellent maiestie at her highnes commynge throughe the said cytie to her coronacion as allso for the furnyture of dyuerse pageantes and other necessaries for the honorable receavinge of her highnes into the same Cytie/At … Cytie: also in Letter Book S, f 182v

div.head: (19 November)
div.ab: Item yt was agreid that there shalbe a Comen counseyll here holden vpon Mondaye nexte comyng at ix of the clock for the grauntyng of ij xvnes for the present that is to be geven to the quenes maiestie by the Cytie att the tyme of her coronacion & for ij xvnesthe provysion of wood & other necessaries for the cominaltye of the seid Cytie/

Item the wardeyns bothe of the parishe clerkes & also of the mynstrelles of this Cytie were here presentlye charged to call seuerallye their hole ffelowships togither & to put theym selfes with all convenyent Spede in good & perfytt redynes to do the beste & moste commenlye servyce that they can for the honour of the seid Cytie/ att the quenes maiesties fyrste comyngeaccession entry of Elizaabeth I vnto the same/ And mr Altham mr Malorye mr Marten & mr Rowe Aldremen were assigned by the Courte to appoynt their stondynges & places & to take order with theym for their decent behauour in the doinge of their seid servyce & to geve theym notyce of the tyme therof/
div.note: The shreves of london to Receyve the quene at her graces first Entre in to Middlesex/
div.ab:
Item ys was agreid that bothe Master Shreves of this Cytie shall Receyve the quenes Maiestie att the vtter parte of the Shere of Middlesex wherof they be also Shreves at the tyme of her highnes entree into the same
Shere in their Cotes of velvett with their Chaynes of gold aboute their neckes and whyte Roddes in their handes whiche roddes they muste kysse and delyuer theym ioyntlye to her grace & Receyving theym bak ageyn from her grace the order is that they muste place theym selfes amongest the gentlemen and so ryde furthe before her Maiestie tyll she come vnto theym ^mayer & Aldremen and then they to take their places with my maisters the Aldermen/

div.head: 7 December
div.note: only using section referring to coronation
Comyners apoyntyd to devyse pageauntes against the quenes maiestes Coronacion /
div.ab:
Item this day the worshipfull Comyners herevnder namyd were nomynatyd appoyntyd & chardgid by the hole Courte to take the chardge Travell & paynes to cause at the Cytyes costes and chardges all the places hereafter mencionyd to be very well and semely trymmyd & deckyd
for the honour of the Cyty agaynste the commynge of our Soueraigne Lady the Quenes maiesty that nowe is to her Coronacion thorroughe the Cyty with pageauntes fyne payntynge and Riche clothes of arras syluer and golde in suche and lyke manner & sorte as they were trymmyd agaynst the commyng of our late Soueraigne lady Quene mary to her Coronacion and moche better if it conveynyently may be done where vnto they agreinge grauntyd to do theire Indeavors That is to sey

list.head: for the Condyt in Cornehill and the Stokes
for the greate Condyt in Cheape
for the lyttle Condyt in Cheape/

div.ab: Item this day Richarde Grafton printer and historian and ffraunces Robynson grocers Richard Hilles merchaunttayllour and Lyonell ducket mercer were assignyd and apoyntyd by the Courte here to survey the doynges and devyses of all the other Comyners of this Cyty which are already apoyntyd to make and devyse suche pageauntes in sundry places of this Cytye agaynste the quenes maiestes commynge to her Coronacion as heretofore hathe byn accustomyd at the lyke tyme and to reforme alter or adde vnto the same as they with thadvyse of suche as they shall call vnto them shall think good and to make reporte here the nexte Courte day by a platte of all theire opynyons and doynges therein and then to vnderstande here what some of money the Cyty hathe in a redynes towardes the doynge therein

Item forasmoche as the paynters of this Cyty dyd vtterly refuse to newe paynte and trym the greate Condyt in Cheape agaynste the Quenes Maiestes comynge to her Coronacion for the Some of xxty markes yt was therefore Orderyd and agryed by the Courte here thys day that the Surveyours of the same shall cause it to be coueryd with Clothes of arras and suche other Ryche Clothes as they can geat and cause certayne Scutchins of the quenes highenes armys to be fynely made & set vpon the same and david playne hed warden of the paynters was commaundyd to attende vpon the said Surveyors of the Condyt & the Surveyors of all the other pageauntes of the Cyty & to help them with his Advyse & workemen for reasonable wages to the best of his powre wherevnto he wyllyngely agryed & promysyd so to do/
Item yt was Orderyd and agryed that Richard Bucland haberdasher shall cause the Carpenter to set vp the Skafold in Saynte Dunstanes Churcheyard
London & lez pore/ in ffletestrete for the childern of the howse of the pore by the day & not be greate and that he se that he and his men do labour honestly and that he kepe well the Reconynge of theire chardges

Item yt was agryed that the bachelers of the mercers Company shalbe permyttyd to stande Togither in Chepe syde dyrectely ouer agaynste the Masters of the same Company on the further syde of the Strete there at the Quenes commynge to her Coronacion

row.cell: Paide the xxiiijth of Decembre vnto Richarde Dawson and Richard Selbye Collectours for ij ffiftenes goinge oute of the Stockes towardes pagentes made for the quenys Maiesties Coronacion quene Elizabeth

div.head: (19 December 1557–18 December 1558)
div.note: & for ij xvtens for ye Citie for and ayenst the Coronacion of quene Elizabeth

row.cell: Paide in Decembre to Thandes of Thomas Williamson and Thomas Stamer Collectours for ij xv.tenes for the furnyture of pagentes ayenst the Coronacion of quene Elizabeth

measure.note: Paide … iiij d.: also in LMA: CLC/L/BA/B/001/MS05177/001, f 150v

div.head: (Charges for setting up rails at coronation of Elizabeth I, 15 January 1558/9)

div.head: (17 November 1558)
div.ab: Anno primo Elizabeth Memorandum that on thursdaye beynge the xvijth daye of Nouember 1558. Queen Elyzabeth Was proclaymed quene at the Standerd in Cheapsyde of london by an haralde of Armes/ at xj of the Clock in the fforenone/ The lord Mayor of london Thomas leighe with his bretherne Thaldermen being in skarlett/ The duke of northfolk With dyuerse others lordes and Busshopps then being present/ at wich tyme were many Capps as well of velvett as other with many gloves throwen awaye for joye and gladnes of her highnes/

row.cell: paid to wolmott ye Carpynder ffor our Standing
xxxviij s.
Item for the hyer of the barge when the Quene dyd come frome Westmynster to the tower
xx s.
Item payed to him that played on the flwyte
ij s.
Item for the frame of the standynge to the ?carpet
xxxix s.
Payed to two men for carryinge of the sayed standynge
ij s.
Payed to iij Wyffelers for iij staves
iij d.
Payed for the caryinge of the Standynge forthe & whome agayne
ij s. viij d.
Payed to ?gaymsheye for the caryage of the standynge at the coronatyon
ij s. iiij d.
Item payd ij fyftenes to ye lorde mayor at ye quenes commyng In
x s.
Item payd for the caryage of our standyng in to vanechirche [Fenchurch] strete at the commyng In of quene elysabyth
xij d.
Item payde [deleted: fo] to ij men for settyng [superscript]vpe[end of superscript] And takyng downe ye standyng
xx d.
Item payd for j C of vpenynyll for the standyng
iiij d.
Item payd for the barge to Westmyster And for Russhes
xiiij s. x d.
Item payd for caryeng of our standyng in to cornell in & owt at the crownenacion of quene elysabyth
xvj d.
Item payd to ij men for settyng vp & takyng downe ye standyng
xvj d.
Item payd for halfe a C of naylles and small cord for ye baners
iij d.

row.cell: paide in decembre for iiij xvtenes to the Citie for pageauntes to be made ayenst the coronacion of quene Elizabeth
vj s.
paide to a paynter for makyng of a newe banner for silke and woorkmanshippe
lx s.

iij li. ij s. v d.
payd to the sayd wyllsdon George Wyllsdon, a collector for Broad Street ward for two xvths grantyde by acte of commen cowncell for the coronacyon of Queene Elyzabethe
xx s.

div.note: The following record is from REED: Civic London to 1558

row.cell: payde Mr Awncyll and Mr shorbucke for ij fyftenes grawntyd to the Citie
v s. iiij d.

Paide the xvijth daie of the moneth of Aprill 1559 for two ffyfteenes/ graunted agayns ye Coronacion of Quene Elizabeth whereof one was given to her maiestie by the lord maior for this Citie and thother was for the ffurnyture of the Pagentes made att the said Coronacione
xxiiij s.

div.head: (19 December) (Quarter day)
div.ab:
x li. gyven to the bachelours towardes there Chardges Also it is Agreed that the Master Bachelers shall calle and Assemble theyem selfes and leaye theire heddes to gedder and consult for the honour of the Cyttye and the worshipe of this Companye for the furnyture of a barge and a foyeste vpon the theames with other goodly order garnishinge decking and furniture thereof in the goodleste and beste maner that can or maye be devysed for the Receyvinge of the Quenes grace from westmester to the tower of London and to corrage theym
to do the same well the Commpanye haue gyven theyem towardes their Charges therof x li. which was neuer sene before ouer and besides iij s. iiij d. a pece of euerye bacheler that waytes and weres his whodde amonges theym/ as they dyde at the mayours going to westmester to take his othe.

order to be taken for there standeng Also at the saide Courte it was agreed that the Lorde Mayour shulde consulte Withe his bretheren thaldermen for order to be hadde and taken consernynge in what place it shalbe thoughte meate that the Bachelers shalle stande in to the fayreste shewe of theym all as the quenes grace shalle passe thorowe this Cittye to her gracious Coronacion and suche order and dyreccyon as his Lordshipe shalle appoyente therin it to be followed and done Accordingly with Diligence

row.cell: [marginal note] a fyftene— / Itm pd for a Subsedie ^xvth^ granted to Quene Mary for oure Hall
vi s. vii d.
Item paid for ii xvth granted agaynst the Crownacion of Quene Elyzabeth
xiij s. iiij d.
